subject: Personal Finance
title: Too Big to Fail
description: A 60-second lesson on Too Big to Fail.

hook.text: When a small bank fails, depositors lose. When a giant bank fails, the whole economy collapses.

buildup.text: 'Too big to fail' means some institutions are so large that their collapse would be catastrophic.

discovery.text: In 2008, the US government bailed out banks with $700 billion in taxpayer money to prevent collapse.

twist.text: This creates moral hazard. If banks know they'll be rescued, they take bigger risks.

climax.text: The Dodd-Frank Act tried to end 'too big to fail.' Critics say the largest banks are even larger now.

punchline.text: Rescue the reckless, and they stay reckless.

quiz.question: What is 'moral hazard' in banking?
options: Banks take more risks knowing they'll be bailed out
Banks become more cautious after crises
